Appendix B Gaussian Differential Privacy (GDP)

Privacy Accountant. Since deep learning needs to iterate over the training data and apply gradient computation multiple times during the training process, each access to the training data incurs some privacy leakage from the overall privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. The total privacy leakage (or loss) of repeated applications of additive noise mechanisms follow from the composition theorems and their refinements [23]. The task of keeping track of the accumulated privacy loss in the course of execution of a composite mechanism, and enforcing the applicable privacy policy, can be performed by the privacy accountant. Abadi et al. [1] proposed moments accountant to provide a tighter bound on the privacy loss compared to the generic advanced composition theorem [24]. Another new and more state-of-the-art privacy accountant method is Gaussian Differential Privacy (GDP) [20, 13], which was shown to obtain a tighter result than moments accountant.

Gaussian Differential Privacy. GDP is a new privacy notion which faithfully retains hypothesis testing interpretation of differential privacy. By leveraging the central limit theorem of Gaussian distribution, GDP has been shown to possess an analytically tractable privacy accountant (vs. moments accountant must be done by numerical computation). Furthermore, GDP can be converted to a collection of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP guarantees (refer to Lemma 4). Note that even in terms of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, the GDP approach gives a tighter privacy accountant than moments accountant. GDP utilizes a single parameter μ⩾0𝜇0\mu\geqslant 0 (called privacy parameter) to quantify the privacy of a randomized mechanism. Similar to the privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon defined in DP, a larger μ𝜇\mu in GDP indicates less privacy guarantee. Comparing with (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, the new notion μ𝜇\mu-GDP can losslessly reason about common primitives associated with differential privacy, including composition, privacy amplification by subsampling, and group privacy. In the following, we briefly introduce some important properties (that will be used in the analysis of our approach) of GDP as below. The formal definition and more detailed results can be found in the original paper [20].

Lemma 1 (Gaussian Mechanism for GDP [20]).

Consider the problem of privately releasing a univariate statistic f​(D)𝑓𝐷f(D) of a dataset D𝐷D. Define the sensitivity of f​(⋅)𝑓⋅f(\cdot) as sf=supD,D′|f​(D)−f​(D′)|subscript𝑠𝑓subscriptsupremum𝐷superscript𝐷′𝑓𝐷𝑓superscript𝐷′s_{f}=\sup_{D,D^{\prime}}|f(D)-f(D^{\prime})|, where the supremum is over all neighboring datasets. Then, the Gaussian mechanism ℳ​(D)=f​(D)+ξℳ𝐷𝑓𝐷𝜉\mathcal{M}(D)=f(D)+\xi, where ξ∼𝒩​(0,sf2/μ2)similar-to𝜉𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑓2superscript𝜇2\xi\sim\mathcal{N}(0,s_{f}^{2}/\mu^{2}), satisfies μ𝜇\mu-GDP.

Lemma 2 (Composition Theorem of GDP [20]).

The m𝑚m-fold composition of μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i}-GDP mechanisms is μ12+⋯+μm2superscriptsubscript𝜇12⋯superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑚2\sqrt{\mu_{1}^{2}+\cdots+\mu_{m}^{2}}-GDP.

Lemma 3 (Group Privacy of GDP [20]).

If a mechanism is μ𝜇\mu-GDP, then it is K​μ𝐾𝜇K\mu-GDP for a group with size K𝐾K.

Lemma 4 (μ𝜇\mu-GDP to (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP [20]).

A mechanism is μ𝜇\mu-GDP if and only if it is (ϵ,δ​(ϵ))italic-ϵ𝛿italic-ϵ(\epsilon,\delta(\epsilon))-DP for all ϵ⩾0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\geqslant 0, where

δ​(ϵ)=Φ​(−ϵμ+μ2)−eϵ⋅Φ​(−ϵμ−μ2),𝛿italic-ϵΦitalic-ϵ𝜇𝜇2⋅superscript𝑒italic-ϵΦitalic-ϵ𝜇𝜇2\displaystyle\delta(\epsilon)=\Phi\left(-\frac{\epsilon}{\mu}+\frac{\mu}{2}\right)-e^{\epsilon}\cdot\Phi\left(-\frac{\epsilon}{\mu}-\frac{\mu}{2}\right),

and ΦΦ\Phi denotes the CDF of standard normal (Gaussian) distribution.

Lemma 5 (Privacy Central Limit Theorem of GDP [13]).

Denote p𝑝p as the subsampling probability, T𝑇T as the total number of iterations and σ𝜎\sigma as the noise scale (i.e., the ratio between the standard deviation of Gaussian noise and the gradient norm bound). Then, algorithm DP-SDG asymptotically satisfies μ𝜇\mu-GDP with privacy parameter μ=p​T​(e1/σ2−1)𝜇𝑝𝑇superscript𝑒1superscript𝜎21\mu=p\sqrt{T(e^{1/\sigma^{2}}-1)}.

In this paper, we use μ𝜇\mu-GDP as our primary privacy accountant method due to its good property on composition and accountant of privacy amplification in Lemma 5, and then convert the result to (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP via Lemma 4. We note that other privacy accountant methods, such as moments accountant [1] and Rényi DP (RDP) [46], are also applicable to the proposed scheme and theoretical analysis, but might lead to suboptimal results.

Appendix C Proof of Privacy (Theorem 1)

We utilize GDP (introduced in Appendix B) as our privacy accountant tool. The two cases in Theorem 1 are discussed as follows.

Case 1: one server and multiple clients are corrupted. We first consider the case when server 𝖲𝖠subscript𝖲𝖠\mathsf{S_{A}} is corrupted by the attacker (the case of corrupting server 𝖲𝖡subscript𝖲𝖡\mathsf{S_{B}} is similar). Recall that server 𝖲𝖠subscript𝖲𝖠\mathsf{S_{A}} receives the share [Δ​θti]𝖠subscriptdelimited-[]Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖𝖠[\Delta\theta_{t}^{i}]_{\mathsf{A}} from client 𝖢i​(∀i∈ℐt)subscript𝖢𝑖for-all𝑖subscriptℐ𝑡\mathsf{C}_{i}~{}(\forall i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}) and the noisy share aggregation [∑i∈ℐt∗Δ​θti]𝖡+[ξt𝖡]𝔽subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖𝖡subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡𝔽[\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*}}\Delta\theta_{t}^{i}]_{\mathsf{B}}+[\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}}]_{\mathbb{F}} from server 𝖲𝖡subscript𝖲𝖡\mathsf{S_{B}}. To infer one record of the victim client 𝖢i​(i∈ℐt∗)subscript𝖢𝑖𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡\mathsf{C}_{i}~{}(i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*}), the attacker can obtain the maximum information from the computation of ∑i∈ℐt∗Δ​θti+ξt𝖡subscript𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*}}\Delta\theta_{t}^{i}+\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}} by adding [∑i∈ℐt∗Δ​θti]𝖠subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖𝖠[\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*}}\Delta\theta_{t}^{i}]_{\mathsf{A}} with [∑i∈ℐt∗Δ​θti]𝖡+ξt𝖡subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖𝖡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡[\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*}}\Delta\theta_{t}^{i}]_{\mathsf{B}}+\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}} and converting the result into a real vector. In the most strong case, where all clients (except the victim 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}) are corrupted, the best that the attacker can do is to compute Δ​θti+ξt𝖡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡\Delta\theta_{t}^{i}+\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}}. On the other hand, since server 𝖲𝖠subscript𝖲𝖠\mathsf{S_{A}} has the information of which iterations that client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i} participates in, the attacker only needs to consider these iterations to infer one record of client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}. By leveraging Lemma 5, we obtain the following Lemma.

Lemma 6 (Privacy against one server and any number of clients).

Assume the attacker corrupts one server (either 𝖲𝖠subscript𝖲𝖠\mathsf{S_{A}} or 𝖲𝖡subscript𝖲𝖡\mathsf{S_{B}}, but not the both) and any number of clients (except the victim client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}). Then, for the benign client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i} who subsamples one record with probability pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}, Algorithm 1 asymptotically satisfies record-level μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i}-GDP with privacy parameter μi=pi​Ti​(e1/σ2−1)subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑇𝑖superscript𝑒1superscript𝜎21\mu_{i}=p_{i}\sqrt{T_{i}(e^{1/\sigma^{2}}-1)}, where Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} is the total number of iterations that client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i} participates in (i.e., selected by the server).

Proof.

Assume the attacker corrupts 𝖲𝖠subscript𝖲𝖠\mathsf{S_{A}}. Denote the set of indices of corrupted clients as 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, where i∉𝒜𝑖𝒜i\notin\mathcal{A} (i.e., except the victim 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}). For any iteration t𝑡t that involves client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i} (i.e., i∈ℐt∗𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*}), the attacker is able to compute ∑i∈ℐt∗,i∉𝒜Δ​θti+ξt𝖡subscriptformulae-sequence𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡𝑖𝒜Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*},i\notin\mathcal{A}}\Delta\theta_{t}^{i}+\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}}, where ξt𝖡∼𝒩​(0,(R​σ)2⋅𝐈)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡𝒩0⋅superscript𝑅𝜎2𝐈\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,(R\sigma)^{2}\cdot\mathbf{I}). Since adding or removing one record in client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}’s dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} would change the value of Δ​θtiΔsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖\Delta\theta_{t}^{i} by at most R𝑅R in terms of ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm due to the record-level clipping on gssubscript𝑔𝑠g_{s} (in Algorithm 2), thus ∑i∈ℐt∗,i∉𝒜Δ​θtisubscriptformulae-sequence𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡𝑖𝒜Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*},i\notin\mathcal{A}}\Delta\theta_{t}^{i} will be changed by at most R𝑅R (i.e., the record-level sensitivity of ∑i∈ℐt∗,i∉𝒜Δ​θtisubscriptformulae-sequence𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡𝑖𝒜Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*},i\notin\mathcal{A}}\Delta\theta_{t}^{i} is R𝑅R). We note that the client-level clipping (with bound C𝐶C) might reduce the influence of one record on the final submission Δ​θtiΔsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖\Delta\theta_{t}^{i}, but never enlarge it. To see why, let’s do some calculations. Based on the notations in Algorithm 2, we denote α=1/max⁡{1,‖Δ​θ~ti‖2/C}𝛼11subscriptnormΔsuperscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑡𝑖2𝐶\alpha=1/\max\{1,~{}\|\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t}^{i}\|_{2}/C\}. According to Line-6 and Line-7 in Algorithm 2, we have Δ​θti=−α​∑s∈𝒮g~sΔsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖𝛼subscript𝑠𝒮subscript~𝑔𝑠\Delta\theta_{t}^{i}=-\alpha\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\tilde{g}_{s}, where ‖g~s‖2⩽Rsubscriptnormsubscript~𝑔𝑠2𝑅\|\tilde{g}_{s}\|_{2}\leqslant R due to the record-level clipping. Therefore, the existence of one record changes Δ​θtiΔsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖\Delta\theta_{t}^{i} at most α​R𝛼𝑅\alpha R in terms of ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm, where α​R⩽R𝛼𝑅𝑅\alpha R\leqslant R because α∈(0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1] by the definition. Since server 𝖲𝖠subscript𝖲𝖠\mathsf{S_{A}} does not know whether a specific record is sampled by client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i} at these iterations (recall that each record is sampled by client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i} with probability pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}), the privacy amplification of record subsampling holds. Note that client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i} only participates in partial of all iterations, and we denote Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} as the total number of iterations that client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i} participates in. According to Lemma 5, with noise 𝒩​(0,(R​σ)2⋅𝐈)𝒩0⋅superscript𝑅𝜎2𝐈\mathcal{N}(0,(R\sigma)^{2}\cdot\mathbf{I}), sensitivity R𝑅R, subsampling probability pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} and total number of iterations Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i}, the privacy parameter of GDP is μi=pi​Ti​(e1/σ2−1)subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑇𝑖superscript𝑒1superscript𝜎21\mu_{i}=p_{i}\sqrt{T_{i}(e^{1/\sigma^{2}}-1)}.

When 𝖲𝖡subscript𝖲𝖡\mathsf{S_{B}} is corrupted by the attacker, the result is the same because the two noises ξt𝖠superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖠\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{A}} and ξt𝖡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}} follow the same distribution. ∎

Case 2: multiple clients are corrupted. Compared with servers, one or multiple corrupted clients (except the victim client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}) possess less information about the private data of client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}, thus the privacy guarantee against the attacker is stronger. For each client who participates in the t𝑡t-th iteration, he/she is able to observe the current model θtsubscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{t}. After observing both θtsubscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{t} and θt+1subscript𝜃𝑡1\theta_{t+1}, one corrupted client 𝖢j​(j≠i)subscript𝖢𝑗𝑗𝑖\mathsf{C}_{j}~{}(j\neq i) can compute ∑i∈ℐt∗,i≠jΔ​θti+ξt𝖠+ξt𝖡subscriptformulae-sequence𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡𝑖𝑗Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖠superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*},i\neq j}\Delta\theta_{t}^{i}+\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{A}}+\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}}, where ξt𝖠+ξt𝖡∼𝒩​(0,2⋅(R​σ)2​𝐈)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖠superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡𝒩0⋅2superscript𝑅𝜎2𝐈\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{A}}+\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,2\cdot(R\sigma)^{2}\mathbf{I}) (note that client 𝖢jsubscript𝖢𝑗\mathsf{C}_{j} knows Δ​θtjΔsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑗\Delta\theta_{t}^{j} but does not know ξt𝖠superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖠\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{A}} or ξt𝖡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}}). The following theorem shows that if any number of clients (excludes client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}) try to collaboratively infer one record of client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}, they cannot do better than keeping track of all θt​(t=1,⋯,T)subscript𝜃𝑡𝑡1⋯𝑇\theta_{t}~{}(t=1,\cdots,T), which is because the Gaussian noise is added by the servers and other clients do not know whether a record is sampled by client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}.

Lemma 7 (Privacy against any number of clients).

Assume the attacker corrupts any number of clients (except the victim client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}). Then, for a benign client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i} who subsamples one record with probability pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}, Algorithm 1 asymptotically satisfies record-level μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i}-GDP with privacy parameter μi=q​pi​T​(e1/(2​σ2)−1)subscript𝜇𝑖𝑞subscript𝑝𝑖𝑇superscript𝑒12superscript𝜎21\mu_{i}=qp_{i}\sqrt{T(e^{1/(2\sigma^{2})}-1)}, where q𝑞q is the probability that a client is selected by the servers in each iteration.

Proof.

Similar to the reasoning in the proof of Lemma 6, adding or removing one record in client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}’s dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} would change the value of Δ​θtiΔsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖\Delta\theta_{t}^{i} by at most R𝑅R in terms of ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm. For any group of malicious clients 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} (except the victim client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i}), they are able to compute ∑i∈ℐt∗,i≠𝒜Δ​θti+ξt𝖠+ξt𝖡subscriptformulae-sequence𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡𝑖𝒜Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖠superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*},i\neq\mathcal{A}}\Delta\theta_{t}^{i}+\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{A}}+\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}}, where ξt𝖠+ξt𝖡∼𝒩​(0,2⋅(R​σ)2​𝐈)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖠superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡𝒩0⋅2superscript𝑅𝜎2𝐈\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{A}}+\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,2\cdot(R\sigma)^{2}\mathbf{I}). Thus, no matter what the size of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, the sensitivity is R𝑅R and the added Gaussian noise is 𝒩​(0,2⋅(R​σ)2​𝐈)𝒩0⋅2superscript𝑅𝜎2𝐈\mathcal{N}(0,2\cdot(R\sigma)^{2}\mathbf{I}). On the other hand, corrupted clients in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} do not know whether client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i} participate at t𝑡t-th iteration (recall that each client is sampled by the servers with probability q𝑞q), thus in their perspective, one specific record of client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i} is subsampled with probability q⋅pi⋅𝑞subscript𝑝𝑖q\cdot p_{i}. According to Lemma 5, with noise 𝒩​(0,2⋅(R​σ)2​𝐈)𝒩0⋅2superscript𝑅𝜎2𝐈\mathcal{N}(0,2\cdot(R\sigma)^{2}\mathbf{I}), sensitivity R𝑅R, subsampling probability q⋅pi⋅𝑞subscript𝑝𝑖q\cdot p_{i} and total number of iterations T𝑇T, the privacy parameter of GDP is μi=q​pi​T​(e1/(2​σ2)−1)subscript𝜇𝑖𝑞subscript𝑝𝑖𝑇superscript𝑒12superscript𝜎21\mu_{i}=qp_{i}\sqrt{T(e^{1/(2\sigma^{2})}-1)}. ∎

Putting two cases together. The value of μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i} in Lemma 6 and Lemma 7 are different for different assumption of the attacker, and by putting them together we obtain the result in (4). Finally, by converting μ𝜇\mu-GDP into (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP (via Lemma 4), we finished the proof of Theorem 1.

Appendix D Proof of Robustness (Theorem 2)

In this section, we show the robustness of PRECAD against model poisoning attacks by leveraging the property of client-level DP, though client-level privacy is not our objective (recall that our privacy goal is to provide record-level privacy). In the following, we first show that releasing the final model θ𝜃\theta satisfies client-level GDP (in Lemma 8). Then, we utilize this result to prove the robustness bounds (i.e., Theorem 2), which shows that the attacker neither can increase nor reduce the expected loss of a record too much.

Lemma 8 (Client-level GDP).

The final model θ=θT𝜃subscript𝜃𝑇\theta=\theta_{T} of Algorithm 1 asymptotically satisfies client-level μ𝜇\mu-GDP for all clients (including malicious clients who implement the model poisoning attack) with privacy parameter

μ=q​T​(e1/σ~2−1)𝜇𝑞𝑇superscript𝑒1superscript~𝜎21\displaystyle\mu=q\sqrt{T(e^{1/\tilde{\sigma}^{2}}-1)} (10)

where σ~=2​σ​R/C~𝜎2𝜎𝑅𝐶\tilde{\sigma}=\sqrt{2}\sigma R/C.

Proof.

We analyze the client-level privacy by keeping track of the model updates at all iterations. Note that adding or removing one client 𝖢jsubscript𝖢𝑗\mathsf{C}_{j}’s output Δ​θtjΔsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑗\Delta\theta_{t}^{j} would change the value of ∑i∈ℐt∗Δ​θtisubscript𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*}}\Delta\theta_{t}^{i} by at most C𝐶C in terms of ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm due to the client-level clipping on Δ​θtiΔsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖\Delta\theta_{t}^{i} (in Algorithm 2). It even holds for malicious clients who do not clip his/her output Δ​θtjΔsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑗\Delta\theta_{t}^{j} by C𝐶C, which will be detected and rejected by servers (via secure validation), then it won’t be included in the set ℐt∗subscriptsuperscriptℐ𝑡\mathcal{I}^{*}_{t}. Thus, the client-level sensitivity of ∑i∈ℐt∗Δ​θtisubscript𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*}}\Delta\theta_{t}^{i} is C𝐶C. On the other hand, the noise added in ∑i∈ℐt∗Δ​θtisubscript𝑖superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑖\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{t}^{*}}\Delta\theta_{t}^{i} can be rewritten as ξt𝖠+ξt𝖡∼𝒩​(0,(C​σ~)2​𝐈)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖠superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡𝒩0superscript𝐶~𝜎2𝐈\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{A}}+\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,(C\tilde{\sigma})^{2}\mathbf{I}) with σ~=2​σ​R/C~𝜎2𝜎𝑅𝐶\tilde{\sigma}=\sqrt{2}\sigma R/C because ξt𝖠+ξt𝖡∼𝒩​(0,2⋅(R​σ)2​𝐈)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖠superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝖡𝒩0⋅2superscript𝑅𝜎2𝐈\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{A}}+\xi_{t}^{\mathsf{B}}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,2\cdot(R\sigma)^{2}\mathbf{I}). Moreover, each client 𝖢jsubscript𝖢𝑗\mathsf{C}_{j} is subsampled with probability q𝑞q. According to Lemma 5, with noise 𝒩​(0,(C​σ~)2​𝐈)𝒩0superscript𝐶~𝜎2𝐈\mathcal{N}(0,(C\tilde{\sigma})^{2}\mathbf{I}), client-level sensitivity C𝐶C, client-level subsampling probability q𝑞q and total number of iterations T𝑇T, the privacy parameter of client-level GDP is μ=q​T​(e1/σ~2−1)𝜇𝑞𝑇superscript𝑒1superscript~𝜎21\mu=q\sqrt{T(e^{1/\tilde{\sigma}^{2}}-1)}. ∎

Now, we are ready to prove the robustness bounds against model poisoning attacks, where the attacker has full control over K𝐾K corrupted (malicious) clients.

Proof of Theorem 2.

According to Lemma 8, randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies client-level μ𝜇\mu-GDP with privacy parameter μ=q​T​(e1/σ~2−1)𝜇𝑞𝑇superscript𝑒1superscript~𝜎21\mu=q\sqrt{T(e^{1/\tilde{\sigma}^{2}}-1)}, where σ~=2​σ​R/C~𝜎2𝜎𝑅𝐶\tilde{\sigma}=\sqrt{2}\sigma R/C. Then, by group privacy of GDP (in Lemma 3), the mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies K​μ𝐾𝜇K\mu-GDP for groups of size K𝐾K. Applying Lemma 4, ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies (ϵ,δ​(ϵ))italic-ϵ𝛿italic-ϵ(\epsilon,\delta(\epsilon))-DP (with client-level group size K𝐾K) for all ϵ⩾0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\geqslant 0, where

δ​(ϵ)=Φ​(−ϵK​μ+K​μ2)−eϵ⋅Φ​(−ϵK​μ−K​μ2)𝛿italic-ϵΦitalic-ϵ𝐾𝜇𝐾𝜇2⋅superscript𝑒italic-ϵΦitalic-ϵ𝐾𝜇𝐾𝜇2\displaystyle\delta(\epsilon)=\Phi\left(-\frac{\epsilon}{K\mu}+\frac{K\mu}{2}\right)-e^{\epsilon}\cdot\Phi\left(-\frac{\epsilon}{K\mu}-\frac{K\mu}{2}\right)

Then, for all ϵ⩾0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\geqslant 0, we have

=\displaystyle=~{} ∫0Bℙθ∼ℳ​(𝒞K′)​[ℓ​(θ,z)>t]​dtsuperscriptsubscript0𝐵subscriptℙsimilar-to𝜃ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒞′𝐾delimited-[]ℓ𝜃𝑧𝑡differential-d𝑡\displaystyle\int_{0}^{B}\mathbb{P}_{\theta\sim\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{C}^{\prime}_{K})}[\ell(\theta,z)>t]\mathrm{d}t
⩽\displaystyle\leqslant~{} eϵ​∫0Bℙθ∼ℳ​(𝒞)​[ℓ​(θ,z)>t]​dt+∫0Bδ​(ϵ)​dtsuperscript𝑒italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript0𝐵subscriptℙsimilar-to𝜃ℳ𝒞delimited-[]ℓ𝜃𝑧𝑡differential-d𝑡superscriptsubscript0𝐵𝛿italic-ϵdifferential-d𝑡\displaystyle e^{\epsilon}\int_{0}^{B}\mathbb{P}_{\theta\sim\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{C})}[\ell(\theta,z)>t]\mathrm{d}t+\int_{0}^{B}\delta(\epsilon)\mathrm{d}t

By denoting ℒℒ\mathcal{L} and ℒK′subscriptsuperscriptℒ′𝐾\mathcal{L}^{\prime}_{K} as in (5), we have

ℒK′⩽infϵ⩾0eϵ⋅ℒ+B​δ​(ϵ)subscriptsuperscriptℒ′𝐾subscriptinfimumitalic-ϵ0⋅superscript𝑒italic-ϵℒ𝐵𝛿italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\prime}_{K}\leqslant\inf_{\epsilon\geqslant 0}~{}e^{\epsilon}\cdot\mathcal{L}+B\delta(\epsilon)

which finishes the proof of (6).

Similarly, for all ϵ⩾0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\geqslant 0, we have

𝔼θ∼ℳ​(𝒞)​[ℓ​(θ,z)]⩽eϵ​𝔼θ∼ℳ​(𝒞K′)​[ℓ​(θ,z)]+B​δ​(ϵ)subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃ℳ𝒞delimited-[]ℓ𝜃𝑧superscript𝑒italic-ϵsubscript𝔼similar-to𝜃ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒞′𝐾delimited-[]ℓ𝜃𝑧𝐵𝛿italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{C})}[\ell(\theta,z)]\leqslant e^{\epsilon}\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{C}^{\prime}_{K})}[\ell(\theta,z)]+B\delta(\epsilon)
⇒⇒\displaystyle\Rightarrow\quad 𝔼θ∼ℳ​(𝒞K′)​[ℓ​(θ,z)]⩾e−ϵ​(𝔼θ∼ℳ​(𝒞)​[ℓ​(θ,z)]−B​δ​(ϵ))subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝒞′𝐾delimited-[]ℓ𝜃𝑧superscript𝑒italic-ϵsubscript𝔼similar-to𝜃ℳ𝒞delimited-[]ℓ𝜃𝑧𝐵𝛿italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{C}^{\prime}_{K})}[\ell(\theta,z)]\geqslant e^{-\epsilon}(\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{C})}[\ell(\theta,z)]-B\delta(\epsilon))

Then,

ℒK′⩾supϵ⩾0e−ϵ⋅(ℒ−B​δ​(ϵ))subscriptsuperscriptℒ′𝐾subscriptsupremumitalic-ϵ0⋅superscript𝑒italic-ϵℒ𝐵𝛿italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\prime}_{K}\geqslant\sup_{\epsilon\geqslant 0}~{}e^{-\epsilon}\cdot(\mathcal{L}-B\delta(\epsilon))

which finishes the proof of (7). ∎

Appendix E Experimental Details

Backdoor Attacks. Following [5], we suppose that the attacker wants the global model to misclassify the images with backdoor features as the targeted labels (i.e., backdoor subtask) while classifying other inputs correctly (i.e., main task). To achieve this, the attacker trains the backdoor model θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*} on a mix of benign examples (i.e., correctly labeled) and backdoor examples (i.e., with backdoor features and modified labels), and then inject it to the global model via a model-replacement methodology (refer to Sec. 3.2). The benign examples can be obtained via accessing the original training dataset of the corrupted (malicious) clients, and the backdoor examples can be obtained by modifying the benign examples or generating new images with the backdoor feature. In this paper, we consider two types of backdoor attacks, which are described as follows:

1) Pixel-Pattern Backdoor (MNIST dataset) [28]. The backdoor examples are generated by changing four pixels in the bottom-right corner of all training images (of corrupted clients) from black to white and labeling them as 0, shown in Figure 6. Since the backdoor feature white pixels in the bottom-right corner does not occur in the original test dataset, we test the accuracy of backdoor subtask on a similarly modified version of the original test dataset (i.e., with white pixels in the bottom-right corner and label 0). Therefore, pixel-pattern backdoor needs to modify images in both training dataset and test dataset, as well as the labels in the training dataset.

2) Semantic Backdoor (CIFAR-10 dataset) [5]. The attacker considers cars with vertical stripes on the background wall (shown in Figure 7) as the backdoor feature and labels them as birds to generate backdoor examples. Following [5], we split the data so that only the attacker has training images with backdoor feature, which avoids the global model to forget the backdoor too fast. Considering the original test dataset only contains 4 images with such backdoor feature, we measure the test accuracy of semantic backdoor on 1,000 randomly rotated and cropped version of the 4 backdoor images. Compared with pixel-pattern backdoor, the advantage of semantic backdoor is that the attacker does not need to modify images.

Backdoor Accuracy. For MNIST dataset, backdoor accuracy is the fraction of classifying images with white bottom-right pixel as 0 (shown in Figure 6). For CIFAR-10 dataset, backdoor accuracy is the fraction of classifying 1,000 randomly rotated and cropped versions of 4 backdoor images (with true label cars, shown in Figure 7) as birds.

Hyperparameters for Training. We fix the leaning rate of the global model as η=0.1𝜂0.1\eta=0.1, the probability of each client is selected by the server as p=0.1𝑝0.1p=0.1, the probability of each record is sampled by client 𝖢isubscript𝖢𝑖\mathsf{C}_{i} as qi=0.05subscript𝑞𝑖0.05q_{i}=0.05. For private training, we set record-level clipping norm bound R=2𝑅2R=2. Note that the value of R𝑅R (which is the sensitivity for record-level privacy) does not affect the privacy accountant of record-level privacy because the standard deviation of added Gaussian noise is proportional to R⋅σ⋅𝑅𝜎R\cdot\sigma, thus the privacy accountant is adjusted by the value of noise multiplier σ𝜎\sigma. For the training of the backdoor model, we set the learning rate as 0.020.020.02 and the number of local iterations as L=5𝐿5L=5 and (vs. L=1𝐿1L=1 for the benign clients). To reduce the influence of randomness on the evaluation, we repeat each experiment with 10 runs and show the averaged results.
